Upon first glance at the question I thought, "That's a horrible thing to even ask. I have six inches or more of snow outside my window, and five more days of this coming. I can't wait for summer." 

The rationale behind this thought is that I have Raynaud's Phenomenon. This is a circulation problem that leaves your extremities completely at the mercy of the cold. Although it isn't a big deal for most people that have it, it is for me. I have primary Raynaud's, which manifests a bit worse than secondary, and the other notable difference is that primary Raynaud's is a stand-alone condition, there isn't a bigger problem that's causing the circulation issues. The slightest coolness or even stress can cause an attack of Raynaud's. There isn't medication for it, so all I can do is take cinnamon and niacin for circulation and bundle up.

My normal winter get-up is pretty comical. If you have seen A Christmas Story remember the scene in which the boys are bundled up so heavily they can't lower their arms. Winter wear isn't far from that for me. Factor in that my job is half outdoors, stocking cold sodas and beer in ill-insulated sheds that are not climate controlled and that one of my co-workers is on heavy medication that causes her to overheat if the mercury hits forty degrees. Imagine a blonde gal swinging open both the doors on the tiny convenience store (due to poor construction they're directly across from each other, no more than twelve feet or so between them) and she's flushed red with heat, hanging out of one of the doors, facing into the biting wind with her eyes shut in pleasure as snowflakes the size of quarters and half-dollar coins fall on her skin and immediately evaporate. Yes, that is steam! Meanwhile, I am dragging an exposed cart of cold product across the parking lot in my marshmallow suit, and thinking of curling up in front of the heater in the back office.

I hate the cold.

Truly.

In the parched, searing hot summers we get in the high desert I spend my free time laying on large, smooth expanses of bedrock sunning myself like the snakes do. Even in the early part of fall, the breeze is only enough to be refreshing and I can relax in a patch of sunshine in the windowsill. In the our soggy spring weather it's often all I can do to stay warm enough to move, but I hang in there with a lot of hot tea and a few good books. In fact, come to think of it I'd miss the other three seasons if it was summer all the time. Half the fun of summer really is the anticipation, however cliche it may sound. So keep it coming, Jack Frost. It just makes me appreciate the summer heat even more.

Also, I have a lovely t-shirt with a Native American theme-- well, I have a few of those, but this one has a raven with a totem-style sun in his talons. I love it, because it's centered around a Tlingit myth about how the sun, moon, and stars came into being. 

Basically a greedy little old man was keeping all the light in the world in a box within a box within a box buried in layers of boxes. Raven found out about this, and transformed himself into a hemlock needle when the old man's daughter went to fetch water from a river, and floated into her basket. She became pregnant, and being a shape-shifter Raven turned himself into something that would easily pass for human in the dark. His "grandfather" was extremely affectionate, as grandparents generally are, and eventually gave in to the Raven-child's tantrums and let him have the outer box. After a while, Raven had quite a few of the boxes and eventually talked Grandpa into letting him hold the light for just a minute. Of course, as soon as he had it, he transformed himself into his normal Raven self, flew off with the light, dropped it, and it shattered into two big pieces and lots of little shards-- the sun, moon, and stars. 

Point being, it's an awesome myth and I always thought it would be kinda cool to get a small tattoo of Raven carrying the light. I'm considering actually getting this tattoo when I get my tax returns.

Last night I scared the bejesus out of everyone. I left a  note saying I'd gone for a walk and would be back by 4 in the morning or thereabouts. I left the house at 2. I had underestimated how upset I was. I couldn't bring myself to turn around and head home when 3 rolled around, not even after the sheriff pulled me over and asked if I was okay or needed a ride. I couldn't bring myself to go home, or call any of my family to pick me up. 

I walked right out of town. 

I thought about walking to Olalla, where Justin lives, but decided against it. I felt no ill feelings toward him, I just didn't want to see anyone right then. So I headed the other way, to Purdy. I almost stopped at the Purdy Spit, to sit on the beach for a while, but I couldn't stop walking. So I kept going. 

I got on the freeway and walked until I got to the Burnham exit. I had walked all the way to Gig Harbor. I stopped briefly in front of the Target and Albertson's stores on top of the hill, and looked at my watch. It had taken me only three hours to walk there. 

I still didn't want to go home, but my legs were cramping up fairly badly by then, and I didn't think they'd take me the remaining distance to where I wanted to go. So I walked around that area of Gig Harbor for about an hour, circling the area over and over again. 

Then I went back to Albertson's. They had a payphone. I had no money on me, not having planned to walk as far as I did. I kept playing with the ring Justin gave me for Christmas, feeling insecure and upset as all Hell still. I had to call though. I couldn't walk anymore. My legs hurt so bad I could barely stand, and was getting stiff and wobbly. So I called Collect. As it turns out, my aunt and uncle do not accept Collect calls, and neither does my  mother. The people Justin lives with do, though. Linda answered, and I kept apologizing for waking her up so early. It was six in the morning, and she sounded really tired. She got ahold of my family, and my uncle picked me up and took me home. 

I feel better now, but that walk only took the edge off of what I was feeling. Apathy is setting in, but it feels temporary, like I'm just in the eye of a bigass emotional storm. Maybe next time I take off I'll have the good sense to take my wallet and my pepperspray with me.

We are less than a month into this relationship. Already we've both helped each other through a moment or two where it seemed the world was crashing down around our ears. Quite frankly, we're both a bit attached to each other and it shows. Our teacher puts up with us playing footsie and making faces in class because it doesn't make us any less productive as students, so that's not a problem. He notices when I'm even the slightest bit stressed, whereas my own family members don't even notice when I've been crying. 

We went out to see a movie tonight. Tomorrow he's going to church with my family and I. For those of you who don't know, I haven't gone to church in a while, and certainly not willingly. I'm actually looking forward to going, sort of. But now I've gotten sidetracked. 

Justin doesn't drive yet and neither do I, so his dad drove me home and then him. Justin had said earlier there was something he wanted to tell me. On the way home he leaned down and whispered, "I love you." 

I don't know how to answer that. Hells yes I like him, and I'm more than a little attached. It felt good to hear it, and goddamn it felt good that it sounded like he meant it. But it scared the tar out of me at the same time. He is not the problem. He's not what scares me. There's nothing scary about him. What scares me is the "love" thing. My father used to use that as a reason why I should obey oppressive commands. My mother has taken over that role. People who say they love me usually either try to control me or they leave me. 

Justin's not the controlling type. He hasn't had many girlfriends before, so he's not a player. But he's left places before. Maybe that shouldn't bother me yet. Especially since he's staying here in Washington (despite the fact that he can't stand the climate here any more than I can) partly because of me. 

My family is rarely ever on my side, and Justin's family apparently mirrors that. Both of us have had to deal recently with thinking we were going to be kicked out. We both have a tendency to put on a good show, pretending we're okay when we aren't. And both of us have recently gone through a time where it seemed like I was the only one on his side, and he was the only one on mine. 

I guess more or less this particular spurt of word-vomiting is for two things: 
1) to help me figure out my own feelings; and
2) to help me figure out how to answer that. 

*sigh* Good night, people.

I cut myself in carving class. The first student to do it, too. Damn I'm clumsy! One of the instructors cut himself too, in a previous class.

Mm. Maybe when I finish I'll just give the carving tools to my brother.

Anyhow, the instructors (there are three) all made a big deal out of it, and everybody acted the way they do at the scene of a carwreck: put down whatever you may be doing and <i>stare.</i> Hehe. It was funny. The cut bled pretty bad, but I kept telling everyone it was just a nick. Turns out I was right. The doctor said the cut is very superficial and should heal in a week. In the meantime, I'm stuck wearing a splint, and have been told to limit the use of my left hand.

The cut's on the knuckle of my left thumb, and it looks worse than it really is. No one can see it now, since it's wrapped in a helluva thick layer of gauze, but it's so minor. I've had papercuts that hurt worse. The doctor thought about a stitch or two, but went with a superglue-like thing called DermaBond instead, since that'll help me keep more mobility. 

The same stroke of the knife that put my thumb out of commision nicked my middle finger, and that's Band-Aided, because that one really is more like a papercut. 

But you'd think they'd teach the nurses to use their brains. The guy <i>heard</i> the doctor tell me to limit the use of my left hand, <i>and</i> warn me that the arm that got the tetanus shot would hurt for a few days. Badly. So the nurse came in and gave me a shot in my <i>right</i> arm. *headdesk* How do these people survive on so little brainpower? 

On the bright side, it looks cool, I get sympathy spoiling, and I get out of chores to some degree! W00t!
